title: Thursday's Markets:  Stocks Stage Broad Rally as Tensions Ease  ----  By Joe Wallace and Michael Wursthorn
text:
Stocks, from health care to technology to financials, rallied, giving major indexes a boost as the euphoria in some of the most overheated segments of the market showed signs of easing.

All 11 sectors of the S&P 500 closed higher, despite relinquishing some of their gains from earlier in the session. Financial, industrial and health-care stocks notched the biggest advances.

Some of the gains followed better-than-expected earnings reports from companies such as American Airlines Group, but much of the green that flashed across the stock market was attributed to opportunistic investors willing to pounce on stocks following their biggest pullback since October, analysts said.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 300.19 points, or 1%, to 30603.36, while the S&P 500 added 36.61 points, or 1%, to 3787.38. The Nasdaq Composite also traded higher, gaining 66.56 points, or 0.5%, to 13337.16. Those gains helped ease losses indexes have suffered throughout the week, with the Dow cutting its decline over the last four trading sessions to 1.3%, while the S&P 500 sits on a 1.4% loss.

At the same time, the euphoria surrounding stocks like GameStop and AMC Entertainment showed signs of abating. GameStop shares fluctuated most of the session before closing down $153.91, or 44%, to $193.60, while AMC stock slumped $11.27, or 57%, to $8.63. The slides coincided with decisions by brokerages like Robinhood Markets and Interactive Brokers Group to restrict the trading of GameStop, AMC and other highflying stocks.

Trading around those two stocks and others had captured the attention of Wall Street and Main Street alike. At its core, internet day traders pitted themselves against short-selling hedge funds, driving a parabolic rise in stocks like GameStop. Trading appeared to hit a fevered pitch Wednesday, as more shares changed hands that day than any other since mid-2019.

The broader stumble in stocks most of the week followed a strong start to the year that some investors say had pushed share prices beyond levels justified by corporate fundamentals and created pockets of excessive enthusiasm within segments of the stock market, including in GameStop shares.

Analysts are urging investors to look past those one-time situations and focus on mostly upbeat earnings.

Nearly a third of the S&P 500 has reported results through Thursday morning, and about 81% have topped analyst's forecasts, according to FactSet data.

"While the behavior of some market participants is reminiscent of historical stock- market bubbles," said Mark Haefele, chief investment officer of global wealth management at UBS Group AG, "we don't believe the market as a whole is in a bubble."

Mr. Haefele and other analysts continue to make the argument that stocks continue to trade at attractive valuations relative to interest rates and bond yields, which remain subdued. UBS believes the S&P 500 could eventually close at 4000 by year-end, a 5.6% gain from current levels.

Quarterly earnings appeared to factor into some of the biggest moves in the stock market on Thursday.

Shares of American Airlines jumped $1.54, or 9.3%, to $18.10 after the airliner reported a narrower loss than analysts had predicted. Other travel stocks rallied, including United Airlines, up $1.64, or 4%, to $42.55, and Carnival, which added 76 cents, or 4%, to $19.74.

Comcast stock added $3.18, or 6.6%, to $51.60 after the company reported growth in its broadband business, pushing results above analysts' forecasts.

Shares of Apple fell $4.97, or 3.5%, to $137.09 after the iPhone maker reported its most profitable three months on record but didn't provide specific revenue guidance for the current quarter.

Tesla dropped $28.73, or 3.3%, to $835.43 after the electric-vehicle maker -- shares of which have soared in recent months -- posted its first full-year profit but missed Wall Street's expectations.

"It is nerve-racking," said Remi Olu-Pitan, a fund manager at Schroders, referring to the big moves in stocks fueled by day traders swapping tips online. "You will see more violent pullbacks," she said, adding that Europe's slow progress on vaccines and Covid-19 restrictions in major economies were also weighing on stocks.

Meanwhile, investors parsed the latest releases of economic data. Weekly applications for unemployment benefits, tracked as an indicator of the health of the labor market, declined last week but remained elevated at 847,000. Separate figures showed gross domestic product, a broad gauge of the value of goods and services produced in the economy, grew at a 4% annual rate in the final quarter, slightly slower than economists had expected.

In one sign of rising risk aversion, the yield on the benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury note dropped below 1% for the first time since Jan. 6 before climbing back to 1.055%. Bond yields fall as prices rise.

The pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 rose 0.1%, while Asian stocks closed lower Thursday. Early Friday, Japan's Nikkei was down 0.2%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng was up 0.5% and South Korea's Kospi was down 0.7%. U.S. stock futures were down 0.6%.

---

Caitlin Ostroff contributed to this article.
